data.about:
Typhoid is a serious bacterial infection caused by *Salmonella* Typhi, transmitted through contaminated food and water, leading to high fever, fatigue, and stomach pain.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/typhoid-fever/index.html)
data.symptoms:
Key symptoms include a prolonged high fever that rises in steps, headache, weakness and fatigue, muscle aches, stomach pain, and either constipation or diarrhea. Some people may develop a rash of flat, rose-colored spots. Without treatment, symptoms worsen and can lead to serious complications.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/typhoid-fever/index.html)
data.prevention:
Prevention relies on vaccination and practicing safe eating and drinking habits. Only consume water that is bottled or has been boiled. Eat food that is thoroughly cooked and still hot. Avoid raw vegetables and fruits you cannot peel yourself. Frequent handwashing is crucial.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/typhoid)
data.transmission:
Typhoid is caused by the bacterium *Salmonella* Typhi and is spread through the fecal-oral route. It is transmitted by ingesting food or water contaminated with the feces of an infected person. Carriers can spread the disease for weeks or even years without showing symptoms.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/typhoid-fever/symptoms-causes/syc-20378661)
data.vaccine:
Yes, two main types of vaccines are available: an injectable conjugate vaccine (recommended from 6 months of age) and an oral live, attenuated vaccine (for those over 6 years). Vaccination is recommended for travelers to endemic areas and people in close contact with carriers.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/typhoid)
data.risk_factors:
Major risk factors include living in or traveling to regions where typhoid fever is common, particularly South Asia. Other risks include being in close contact with an infected person, having a weakened immune system, and drinking or eating contaminated water or food.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/typhoid-fever/index.html)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that typhoid is just a severe stomach flu; it is a serious bacterial infection that can be fatal if not treated with antibiotics. Another myth is that it's spread through the air; it is only transmitted through contaminated food and water.
Source: Johns Hopkins (https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/conditions-and-diseases/typhoid-fever)
data.cure:
Typhoid fever is treated with antibiotics, which are highly effective at curing the infection. Prompt treatment is crucial to prevent complications. Common antibiotics include azithromycin and ceftriaxone.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/typhoid-fever/treatment.html)

data.about:
Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES) is a neurological condition characterized by the acute onset of fever and mental status changes, caused by a wide range of viruses, bacteria, and other agents.
Source: NCDC India (https://ncdc.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=2&sublinkid=367&lid=324)
data.symptoms:
Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES) is characterized by the acute onset of fever and a change in mental status, such as confusion, disorientation, delirium, or coma. Other neurological symptoms can include seizures, limb weakness, and cranial nerve palsies.
Source: NCDC India (https://ncdc.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=2&sublinkid=367&lid=324)
data.prevention:
Prevention strategies depend on the specific cause. For Japanese Encephalitis virus (a major cause), vaccination is the most effective tool. General measures include mosquito control (using nets, repellents), maintaining good hygiene, and ensuring access to safe drinking water. In some areas, avoiding consumption of unripe lychees on an empty stomach is advised for children.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/japanese-encephalitis)
data.transmission:
AES is a syndrome caused by various agents, including viruses, bacteria, fungi, and toxins. Transmission varies by the agent. Viruses like Japanese Encephalitis are transmitted by mosquito bites. Other causes are not transmissible from person to person.
Source: NCDC India (https://ncdc.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=2&sublinkid=367&lid=324)
data.vaccine:
A vaccine is available for Japanese Encephalitis (JE), which is a leading cause of AES in many parts of Asia, including India. However, there is no single vaccine for AES itself, as it has multiple causes.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/japanese-encephalitis)
data.risk_factors:
Risk factors are often age-related, with children being most vulnerable. Living in rural or agricultural areas where vectors like mosquitoes are prevalent increases risk. Malnutrition and a weakened immune system can also be contributing factors.
Source: The Lancet (https://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(17)30256-5/fulltext)
data.misconceptions:
A major misconception is that 'Chamki Bukhar' is a single disease. It is a neurological syndrome with dozens of possible causes. Another misunderstanding is that lychees are the sole cause; they are linked to a specific metabolic illness that can cause AES-like symptoms in malnourished children, but they are not responsible for most cases.
Source: Indian J Pediatr (https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12098-019-03061-6)
data.cure:
There is no specific cure for AES itself. Treatment is symptomatic and supportive, focusing on managing fever, seizures, and maintaining hydration and electrolyte balance. The specific treatment depends on the underlying causative agent (e.g., antiviral drugs for some viral causes).
Source: NCDC India (https://ncdc.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=2&sublinkid=367&lid=324)

data.about:
Diphtheria is a serious bacterial infection caused by *Corynebacterium diphtheriae* that can lead to a thick covering in the back of the throat, causing breathing difficulty, heart problems, and nerve damage.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/diphtheria/symptoms-causes/syc-20351897)
data.symptoms:
Symptoms include a thick, gray membrane covering the throat and tonsils, a sore throat and hoarseness, swollen glands (bull neck), difficulty breathing or rapid breathing, nasal discharge, fever, and chills. The bacterial toxin can also damage the heart, kidneys, and nerves.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/diphtheria/symptoms-causes/syc-20351897)
data.prevention:
The most effective way to prevent diphtheria is through routine vaccination. The DTaP vaccine for children and the Tdap/Td booster for adolescents and adults protect against diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis (whooping cough).
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/diphtheria/vaccination.html)
data.transmission:
Diphtheria is caused by the bacterium *Corynebacterium diphtheriae*. It spreads from person to person, usually through respiratory droplets from coughing or sneezing. People can also get it by touching infected open sores or ulcers.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/diphtheria)
data.vaccine:
Yes, highly effective vaccines exist. It is usually given in combination with vaccines for tetanus and whooping cough (e.g., DTaP, Tdap). A full course of vaccination provides long-term protection, with boosters recommended every 10 years.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/diphtheria/vaccination.html)
data.risk_factors:
Individuals who are unvaccinated or not up-to-date on their booster shots are at the highest risk. Other risk factors include living in crowded or unsanitary conditions and having a weakened immune system.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/diphtheria/symptoms-causes/syc-20351897)
data.misconceptions:
A common myth is that diphtheria is a disease of the past. While rare in countries with high vaccination rates, it still causes outbreaks and is a threat in areas with low immunization coverage. It is a bacterial infection, not a viral one.
Source: Immunize.org (https://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_dip.asp)
data.cure:
Treatment for diphtheria is a two-part approach involving a diphtheria antitoxin to neutralize the toxin that has not yet bound to cells, and antibiotics (such as penicillin or erythromycin) to kill the bacteria and stop toxin production. It is crucial to start treatment immediately.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/diphtheria/treatment.html)

data.about:
Bird flu, or avian influenza, is a disease caused by a virus that primarily infects birds but can spread to humans through direct contact, causing symptoms from mild flu to severe respiratory illness.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/flu/avianflu/index.htm)
data.symptoms:
In humans, symptoms of avian influenza (Bird Flu) can range from mild flu-like symptoms (fever, cough, sore throat, muscle aches) to severe respiratory illness, pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and neurological changes. Eye infections (conjunctivitis) can also occur.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/flu/avianflu/index.htm)
data.prevention:
The primary prevention method is to avoid sources of exposure. This includes avoiding contact with wild birds and sick or dead poultry. Practice good hand hygiene after contact with birds or their environments. All poultry and eggs should be cooked thoroughly.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/avian-influenza-a(h5n1)))
data.transmission:
Bird flu viruses primarily infect and spread among birds. Humans can be infected through direct contact with infected birds (live or dead) or their contaminated feces, saliva, or nasal secretions. Sustained human-to-human transmission is rare but a public health concern.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/flu/avianflu/index.htm)
data.vaccine:
There is no widely available vaccine for the general public. However, vaccines for some strains (like H5N1) have been developed and are held in stockpiles by governments for use in the event of a pandemic.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/avian-influenza-a(h5n1)))
data.risk_factors:
Risk factors for human infection include direct or close contact with infected poultry, such as during farming, slaughtering, or food preparation. Visiting live bird markets is also a significant risk factor in affected areas.
Source: NHS UK (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/bird-flu/)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that you can get bird flu from eating properly cooked chicken or eggs. The virus is destroyed by heat, making properly handled and cooked poultry safe to eat. The risk to the general public is very low; it is primarily an occupational risk for poultry workers.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/flu/avianflu/prevention.htm)
data.cure:
Treatment for human infection with avian influenza viruses involves antiviral drugs, most commonly oseltamivir (Tamiflu). Treatment should begin as soon as possible after symptoms appear. Supportive care in a hospital may be necessary for severe cases.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/flu/avianflu/prevention.htm)

data.about:
Kala-azar, or Visceral Leishmaniasis, is a severe parasitic disease transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies, characterized by prolonged fever, weight loss, and enlargement of the spleen and liver.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/leishmaniasis)
data.symptoms:
Also known as Visceral Leishmaniasis, symptoms include irregular bouts of fever over a long period, substantial weight loss, enlargement of the spleen and liver, and anemia. The skin may become dark, dry, and scaly, which gives it the name Kala-azar ('black fever').
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/leishmaniasis)
data.prevention:
Prevention focuses on avoiding sandfly bites. Measures include using insect repellent on exposed skin, sleeping under insecticide-treated bed nets, wearing protective clothing, and keeping home environments clean to reduce sandfly breeding sites.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/leishmaniasis/prevent.html)
data.transmission:
Kala-azar is a parasitic disease caused by *Leishmania* protozoa and is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies. The sandflies become infected by biting an infected animal or human.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/leishmaniasis)
data.vaccine:
Currently, there is no vaccine or preventive drug for Kala-azar in humans. Research into developing a vaccine is ongoing.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/parasites/leishmaniasis/prevent.html)
data.risk_factors:
Risk factors are linked to poverty, including malnutrition, poor housing, and a weak immune system. Environmental factors like deforestation and urbanization that bring humans into closer contact with sandfly habitats also increase risk.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/leishmaniasis)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that Kala-azar is directly contagious from person to person; it can only be transmitted through the bite of an infected sandfly. Another myth is that it is simply a fever; it is a serious parasitic disease that is fatal if left untreated.
Source: DNDi (https://dndi.org/diseases/visceral-leishmaniasis/)
data.cure:
Kala-azar is a curable disease. Treatment involves a full course of anti-leishmanial medicines. The choice of drug depends on the region and the specific *Leishmania* species. If left untreated, the disease is almost always fatal.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/leishmaniasis)

data.about:
Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) is a highly contagious viral infection common in young children that causes painful sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/index.html)
data.symptoms:
Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) causes fever, sore throat, and painful sores inside the mouth. It's followed by a rash of flat red spots or blisters on the palms of the hands, soles of the feet, knees, elbows, and buttocks. 'Tomato Flu' is a colloquial term for an HFMD variant with larger, red blisters.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/index.html)
data.prevention:
Prevention involves frequent handwashing with soap and water, especially after using the toilet or changing diapers. Disinfect frequently touched surfaces and toys. Avoid close contact such as kissing, hugging, or sharing utensils with infected people.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/hand-foot-and-mouth-disease/symptoms-causes/syc-20353035)
data.transmission:
HFMD is very contagious and is spread through person-to-person contact with an infected person's nasal secretions, saliva, blister fluid, or stool. It can also be spread by respiratory droplets released when an infected person coughs or sneezes.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/index.html)
data.vaccine:
There is no specific vaccine to protect against the viruses that cause HFMD in most parts of the world, including the US and Europe. Vaccines have been developed and are used in China against one specific virus (EV-A71) that can cause severe HFMD.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/westernpacific/health-topics/hand-foot-and-mouth-disease)
data.risk_factors:
Infants and children under the age of 5 are most at risk for HFMD. The risk increases for children in daycare or school settings where infections can spread quickly.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/hand-foot-and-mouth-disease/symptoms-causes/syc-20353035)
data.misconceptions:
A major misconception is that 'Tomato Flu' is a new or separate disease. It is a clinical variant of HFMD and is not caused by a new virus. It has no connection to tomatoes. Another myth is that it is related to foot-and-mouth disease, which affects livestock; they are completely different diseases caused by different viruses.
Source: The Lancet (https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanres/article/PIIS2213-2600(22)00300-9/fulltext)
data.cure:
There is no specific cure or vaccine for Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease. Treatment is focused on relieving symptoms. Pain and fever can be managed with over-the-counter medications, while mouth sores can be soothed with mouthwashes or sprays. Most children recover completely within 7 to 10 days.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/about/treatment.html)

data.about:
Cancer is a non-communicable disease (NCD) defined as a chronic disease that is not transmissible from one person to another—it is not contagious. Cancer is broadly classified based on the type of cell it originates from. The main categories include **Carcinoma**, which starts in the skin or tissues lining organs; **Sarcoma**, cancer of connective tissues like bone and muscle; **Leukemia**, cancer of blood-forming tissue; and **Lymphoma and Myeloma**, which begin in immune system cells.
Source: NCI (https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/understanding/what-is-cancer)
It is a non-communicable disease (NCD), meaning it is not contagious from person to person.
Source: NP-NCD (https://www.mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/NP-NCD%20Operational%20Guidelines_0.pdf) 
In India, the most common cancers in men are lung, mouth, stomach, and oesophagus. Among women, breast and cervical cancers are the most frequent.
Source: ICMR (https://www.icmr.gov.in/icmrobject/custom_data/1720337709_ncrp_2020_2012_16.pdf)
data.symptoms:
Symptoms are extremely varied and depend on the cancer's location and size. General signs can include fatigue, a lump or area of thickening, unexplained weight loss or gain, skin changes, persistent cough, changes in bowel or bladder habits, and unusual bleeding or discharge.
Source: NCI (https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/understanding/what-is-cancer)
data.prevention:
Prevention involves lifestyle choices like not using tobacco, maintaining a healthy weight through diet and exercise, protecting your skin from the sun, limiting alcohol consumption, and getting vaccinated against cancer-causing infections like HPV and Hepatitis B. Regular screening tests are also vital.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/cancer)
data.transmission:
Cancer is not a communicable disease; you cannot 'catch' it from another person. It arises from genetic mutations in a person's own cells. However, certain viruses and bacteria that can increase cancer risk (e.g., HPV, H. pylori) can be transmitted between people.
Source: Cancer.Net (https://www.cancer.net/navigating-cancer-care/cancer-basics/what-cancer/cancer-communicable-disease)
data.vaccine:
There is no vaccine for cancer itself. However, vaccines exist that can prevent cancers caused by specific viruses. The Human Papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine prevents most cervical, anal, and throat cancers, and the Hepatitis B vaccine helps prevent liver cancer.
Source: NCI (https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/causes-prevention/vaccines)
data.risk_factors:
Major risk factors include aging, tobacco use, alcohol use, sun exposure, obesity, family history of cancer, and exposure to certain chemicals or radiation. Some chronic infections are also significant risk factors.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/cancer)
data.misconceptions:
A pervasive myth is that sugar 'feeds' cancer. While cancer cells consume sugar, there is no evidence that eating sugar will make cancer worse or that avoiding it will make it go away. Another misconception is that cancer is always a death sentence; treatment outcomes have improved dramatically, and many cancers are curable.
Source: Cancer Research UK (https://www.cancerresearchuk.org/about-cancer/causes-of-cancer/diet-and-cancer/sugar-and-cancer)
data.cure:
There is no single cure for cancer. Treatment depends on the type and stage of cancer and may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, or hormone therapy. Many cancers can be cured, especially if detected early, while others can be managed as chronic diseases.
Source: NCI (https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment)

data.about:
Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS) is the late stage of infection with the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV), which severely damages the immune system, leading to opportunistic infections and cancers. There are two main types of the virus: **HIV-1**, the most common type found worldwide, and **HIV-2**, which is less common, less easily transmitted, and primarily found in West Africa. Essentially, HIV attacks the body's vital immune cells, and without treatment, this damage can progress to AIDS, the most advanced stage where the body can no longer defend against infections.
Source: HIV.gov (https://www.hiv.gov/hiv-basics/overview/about-hiv-and-aids/what-are-hiv-and-aids)
data.symptoms:
Early HIV can cause flu-like symptoms (fever, chills, rash, sore throat). If untreated, it progresses to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS). AIDS is defined by a severely damaged immune system, leading to opportunistic infections, certain cancers, severe weight loss, and neurological problems.
Source: HIV.gov (https://www.hiv.gov/hiv-basics/overview/about-hiv-and-aids/what-are-hiv-and-aids)
data.prevention:
Prevention methods include using condoms consistently, never sharing needles or syringes, and using preventive medicines such as PrEP (pre-exposure prophylaxis) for high-risk individuals and PEP (post-exposure prophylaxis) after a potential exposure. Testing and treatment also prevent transmission.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/basics/prevention.html)
data.transmission:
HIV is transmitted through specific bodily fluids from an infected person: blood, semen, pre-seminal fluid, vaginal fluids, rectal fluids, and breast milk. It is most commonly spread through unprotected sex or sharing injection drug equipment.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/hiv-aids)
data.vaccine:
There is currently no vaccine to prevent or cure HIV infection. However, significant research efforts are underway to develop one. Antiretroviral therapy (ART) can control the virus effectively, but it is not a cure.
Source: NIH (https://www.niaid.nih.gov/diseases-conditions/hiv-vaccine-development)
data.risk_factors:
Key risk factors include having unprotected anal or vaginal sex with someone who has HIV, having another sexually transmitted infection (STI), sharing needles or syringes, and receiving unsafe injections or blood transfusions.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/hiv-aids/symptoms-causes/syc-20373524)
data.misconceptions:
A major misconception is that HIV can be spread through casual contact like hugging, sharing food, or from toilet seats or insect bites; this is false. A crucial fact is U=U (Undetectable equals Untransmittable), meaning people with HIV who maintain an undetectable viral load through treatment cannot sexually transmit the virus to others.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/basics/u-equals-u.html)
data.cure:
There is no cure for HIV, but it can be controlled with effective medical care. Treatment with a combination of medicines called antiretroviral therapy (ART) can reduce the amount of HIV in the body (viral load) to an undetectable level, allowing people with HIV to live long, healthy lives and preventing transmission to others.
Source: HIV.gov (https://hivinfo.nih.gov/understanding-hiv/fact-sheets/hiv-treatment-basics)

data.about:
Piles, also known as hemorrhoids, are a non-contagious condition involving swollen veins in the anus and lower rectum that can cause bleeding, itching, and discomfort during bowel movements.
Source: NHS UK (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/piles-haemorrhoids/)
data.symptoms:
Also known as hemorrhoids, symptoms include painless bleeding during bowel movements (bright red blood), itching or irritation in the anal region, pain or discomfort, a lump near the anus which may be sensitive or painful, and swelling around the anus.
Source: NHS UK (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/piles-haemorrhoids/)
data.prevention:
Prevention focuses on keeping stools soft and easy to pass. This includes eating a high-fiber diet (fruits, vegetables, whole grains), drinking plenty of water, avoiding straining during bowel movements, exercising, and not sitting on the toilet for extended periods.
Source: NIDDK (https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/digestive-diseases/hemorrhoids/prevention)
data.transmission:
Piles are not contagious. They are a physical condition involving swollen veins in the anus and lower rectum, similar to varicose veins. They cannot be passed from one person to another.
Source: Harvard Health (https://www.health.harvard.edu/diseases-and-conditions/hemorrhoids-and-what-to-do-about-them)
data.vaccine:
There is no vaccine for piles because it is not an infectious disease caused by a pathogen. It is a structural and physiological condition.
Source: Cleveland Clinic (https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/15120-hemorrhoids)
data.risk_factors:
Risk factors include chronic constipation or diarrhea, straining during bowel movements, sitting for long periods on the toilet, obesity, pregnancy, a low-fiber diet, and regular heavy lifting.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/hemorrhoids/symptoms-causes/syc-20360268)
data.misconceptions:
A common myth is that sitting on cold surfaces causes piles; this is untrue. Another misconception is that only older people get them, but they can occur at any age, especially due to diet and lifestyle. Piles are not cancerous and do not increase the risk of cancer.
Source: ASCRS (https://fascrs.org/patients/diseases-and-conditions/a-z/hemorrhoids)
data.cure:
Piles can often be cured with simple diet and lifestyle changes, such as increasing fiber and fluid intake. Over-the-counter creams can relieve symptoms. For persistent or severe hemorrhoids, hospital treatments like banding or surgery can remove them effectively.
Source: NHS UK (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/piles-haemorrhoids/treatment/)

data.about:
Chickenpox is a highly contagious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus, known for its characteristic itchy rash of fluid-filled blisters that spreads across the body.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/chickenpox/index.html)
data.symptoms:
The classic symptom is a very itchy rash of small, fluid-filled blisters that typically appears first on the chest, back, and face, then spreads to the rest of the body. Other symptoms that may appear 1-2 days before the rash include fever, loss of appetite, headache, and fatigue.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/chickenpox/index.html)
data.prevention:
The best way to prevent chickenpox is to get the chickenpox (varicella) vaccine. Two doses of the vaccine are about 90% effective at preventing the disease. Avoiding contact with an infected person is also important.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/chickenpox/symptoms-causes/syc-20351282)
data.transmission:
Chickenpox is highly contagious. It is caused by the varicella-zoster virus and spreads easily from an infected person to others through the air by coughing and sneezing, or by direct contact with fluid from the chickenpox blisters.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/health-topics/chickenpox)
data.vaccine:
Yes, a safe and effective varicella vaccine is available and is part of the routine childhood immunization schedule in many countries. Two doses are recommended for children, adolescents, and adults who have never had chickenpox.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/chickenpox/index.html)
data.risk_factors:
The biggest risk factor is not having had chickenpox or the vaccine. It is most common in children under 10. Adults who get it are at higher risk for complications. People with weakened immune systems and newborns are also at high risk.
Source: NHS UK (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/chickenpox/)
data.misconceptions:
A dangerous misconception is that chickenpox is a harmless childhood 'rite of passage'. It can lead to serious complications, including bacterial skin infections, pneumonia, and encephalitis (inflammation of the brain). Another myth is that you can't get it more than once; while rare, second infections can occur.
Source: HealthyChildren.org (https://www.healthychildren.org/English/health-issues/conditions/skin/Pages/Chickenpox.aspx)
data.cure:
There is no specific cure for chickenpox as the body's immune system typically clears the virus. Treatment focuses on relieving symptoms like itching with calamine lotion and cool baths. For people at high risk of complications, doctors may prescribe antiviral drugs like acyclovir to shorten the duration of the infection.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/chickenpox/diagnosis-treatment/drc-20351287)

data.about:
Thyroid disorders are conditions that affect the thyroid gland, a butterfly-shaped gland in the neck that produces hormones regulating metabolism. The most common issues are hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid) and hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid).
Source: American Thyroid Association (https://www.thyroid.org/thyroid-information/)
data.symptoms:
Symptoms vary. Hypothyroidism (underactive) can cause fatigue, weight gain, constipation, dry skin, and sensitivity to cold. Hyperthyroidism (overactive) may cause weight loss, rapid heartbeat, anxiety, tremors, and sensitivity to heat.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/hyperthyroidism/symptoms-causes/syc-20373659)
data.prevention:
Most thyroid disorders are not preventable. However, preventing iodine deficiency through a balanced diet can prevent some types, such as goiters. Autoimmune thyroid diseases like Hashimoto's or Graves' disease cannot be prevented.
Source: Cleveland Clinic (https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/8541-thyroid-disease)
data.transmission:
Thyroid disorders are not contagious. They are physiological or autoimmune conditions and cannot be spread from person to person.
Source: NHS UK (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/overactive-thyroid-hyperthyroidism/)
data.vaccine:
There is no vaccine for thyroid disorders as they are not caused by an infectious agent.
Source: Johns Hopkins Medicine (https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/conditions-and-diseases/thyroid-disorders)
data.risk_factors:
Risk factors include being female, having a family history of thyroid disease, having an autoimmune condition (like Type 1 diabetes), and previous radiation treatment to the neck or chest. Iodine deficiency is also a global risk factor.
Source: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/endocrine-diseases/hypothyroidism)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that all thyroid problems cause weight gain; hyperthyroidism often causes weight loss. Another myth is that thyroid nodules are always cancerous; in fact, over 90% are benign (non-cancerous).
Source: American Cancer Society (https://www.cancer.org/cancer/types/thyroid-cancer/detection-diagnosis-staging/signs-symptoms.html)
data.cure:
There is no cure for most types of thyroid disorders, such as autoimmune conditions like Hashimoto's or Graves' disease. However, they are manageable. Hypothyroidism is treated with lifelong hormone replacement therapy. Hyperthyroidism can sometimes be effectively cured through treatments like radioactive iodine or surgical removal of the thyroid gland, though this results in hypothyroidism requiring lifelong treatment.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/hypothyroidism/diagnosis-treatment/drc-20350289)

data.about:
A lipoma is a non-cancerous (benign) tumor made of fat tissue. They are generally soft to the touch, movable, and painless, typically found just under the skin on the neck, shoulders, back, or arms.
Source: Cleveland Clinic (https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/15006-lipoma)
data.symptoms:
The primary sign is a small, soft, doughy lump just beneath the skin. They are typically less than 2 inches in diameter and grow very slowly. They are usually painless unless they grow and press on nearby nerves or contain many blood vessels.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/lipoma/symptoms-causes/syc-20374470)
data.prevention:
There is no known way to prevent lipomas. They are often inherited, suggesting a genetic factor plays a role in their development.
Source: Johns Hopkins Medicine (https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/conditions-and-diseases/lipoma)
data.transmission:
Lipomas are not contagious. They are a benign growth of fat cells and cannot be transmitted from one person to another.
Source: Stanford Medicine (https://stanfordhealthcare.org/medical-conditions/cancer/lipoma.html)
data.vaccine:
There is no vaccine for lipomas, as they are a non-infectious tissue growth, not a disease caused by a pathogen.
Source: Cleveland Clinic (https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/15006-lipoma)
data.risk_factors:
Lipomas can occur at any age but are most common in people between 40 and 60 years old. A family history of lipomas increases the risk. Certain rare genetic conditions can also cause multiple lipomas to form.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/lipoma/symptoms-causes/syc-20374470)
data.misconceptions:
The most common misconception is that a lipoma is a form of cancer. Lipomas are benign, and it is extremely rare for one to become a cancerous liposarcoma. They are not caused by being overweight.
Source: Healthline (https://www.healthline.com/health/skin/lipoma)
data.cure:
Lipomas are typically cured by simple surgical excision or liposuction. Once a lipoma is completely removed, it usually does not grow back. Treatment is often not medically necessary unless the lipoma is painful, growing, or causes cosmetic concern.
Source: Cleveland Clinic (https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/15006-lipoma)

data.about:
Arthritis is the swelling and tenderness of one or more joints, leading to pain and stiffness. The most common types are osteoarthritis, which involves wear-and-tear damage to cartilage, and rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune disease where the body attacks the joints.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/arthritis/basics/index.html)
data.symptoms:
Common symptoms include joint pain, stiffness (especially in the morning), swelling, redness, and decreased range of motion. Symptoms can range from mild to severe and may come and go.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/arthritis/symptoms-causes/syc-20350772)
data.prevention:
While some types cannot be prevented, you can reduce the risk of others. Maintaining a healthy weight, controlling blood sugar, exercising, and preventing joint injuries can help prevent osteoarthritis.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/arthritis/basics/prevention.html)
data.transmission:
Arthritis is not a contagious disease. It cannot be passed from one person to another. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder, and osteoarthritis is primarily due to mechanical wear and tear.
Source: Arthritis Foundation (https://www.arthritis.org/health-wellness/about-arthritis/understanding-arthritis/what-is-arthritis)
data.vaccine:
There is no vaccine for arthritis. It is a non-infectious condition related to inflammation, autoimmune activity, or joint degradation.
Source: Johns Hopkins Medicine (https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/conditions-and-diseases/arthritis)
data.risk_factors:
Key risk factors include a family history, older age, being female (for rheumatoid arthritis), previous joint injury, and obesity, which puts extra stress on joints like the knees and hips.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/arthritis/symptoms-causes/syc-20350772)
data.misconceptions:
A common myth is that arthritis is an inevitable part of aging; while risk increases with age, it is not a normal part of the aging process. Another misconception is that exercise makes it worse; in fact, proper exercise can reduce pain and improve function.
Source: Arthritis Foundation (https://www.arthritis.org/health-wellness/healthy-living/managing-pain/pain-relief-solutions/6-arthritis-myths-busted)
data.cure:
There is no cure for most forms of arthritis, including osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis. Treatment focuses on managing pain, reducing inflammation, improving joint function, and slowing disease progression through medication, physical therapy, and lifestyle changes. In severe cases, joint replacement surgery can alleviate symptoms but does not cure the underlying condition.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/arthritis/basics/faqs.htm)

data.about:
A stroke is a medical emergency that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. The main types are ischemic (blocked artery) and hemorrhagic (leaking or burst blood vessel).
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/stroke/about.htm)
data.symptoms:
Symptoms appear suddenly and include numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg (especially on one side); confusion, trouble speaking or understanding speech; trouble seeing; and a sudden, severe headache. The F.A.S.T. acronym (Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call for help) is used to spot signs.
Source: American Stroke Association (https://www.stroke.org/en/about-stroke/stroke-symptoms)
data.prevention:
Up to 80% of strokes are preventable. Prevention involves managing blood pressure, not smoking, maintaining a healthy weight, eating a healthy diet, exercising regularly, and managing conditions like diabetes and atrial fibrillation.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/cardiovascular-diseases-(cvds))
data.transmission:
A stroke is not contagious. It is a cardiovascular event that occurs within a person's brain and cannot be spread to others.
Source: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (https://www.ninds.nih.gov/health-information/disorders/stroke)
data.vaccine:
There is no vaccine for stroke because it is not an infectious disease. It is a result of underlying cardiovascular issues.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/stroke/about.htm)
data.risk_factors:
Major risk factors include high blood pressure, high cholesterol, smoking, obesity, and diabetes. Other factors include a family history of stroke, older age, and certain heart conditions like atrial fibrillation.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/stroke/symptoms-causes/syc-20350113)
data.misconceptions:
A common myth is that strokes only happen to elderly people; they can occur at any age. Another misconception is that recovery only happens in the first few months; in reality, recovery can be a lifelong process.
Source: American Stroke Association (https://www.stroke.org/en/about-stroke/stroke-myths-and-facts)
data.cure:
A stroke is a medical event, not a disease that can be 'cured.' The damage done to the brain from a stroke can be permanent. Treatment focuses on two stages: immediate emergency care to stop the stroke and restore blood flow, and post-stroke rehabilitation to help the individual recover lost skills and function. Prevention of a future stroke is a key part of long-term care.
Source: American Stroke Association (https://www.stroke.org/en/about-stroke/stroke-risk-factors/stroke-prevention-vs-cure)

data.about:
Diabetes is a chronic disease that occurs when the pancreas does not produce enough insulin or when the body cannot effectively use the insulin it produces, leading to high blood glucose (blood sugar). The main types are Type 1, Type 2, and gestational diabetes.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/diabetes)
data.symptoms:
Symptoms include frequent urination, increased thirst, unexplained weight loss, increased hunger, fatigue, and blurred vision. In Type 1, symptoms can develop quickly; in Type 2, they are often gradual and may go unnoticed for years.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/basics/symptoms.html)
data.prevention:
Type 1 diabetes cannot be prevented. Type 2 diabetes can often be prevented or delayed through a healthy lifestyle, including maintaining a healthy body weight, being physically active, and eating a healthy diet.
Source: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/diabetes/overview/preventing-type-2-diabetes)
data.transmission:
Diabetes is not contagious. It is a metabolic disorder and cannot be passed from person to person through contact.
Source: American Diabetes Association (https://diabetes.org/about-diabetes)
data.vaccine:
There is no vaccine for diabetes. Research is ongoing, particularly for a vaccine to prevent Type 1 diabetes, which is an autoimmune disease.
Source: JDRF (https://www.jdrf.org/t1d-resources/about/)
data.risk_factors:
For Type 1, risk factors include family history. For Type 2, risks include being overweight, physical inactivity, family history, and age (over 45). Gestational diabetes occurs during pregnancy.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/basics/risk-factors.html)
data.misconceptions:
A common myth is that eating too much sugar causes diabetes; while a high-sugar diet can lead to obesity (a risk factor), sugar itself isn't the direct cause. Another misconception is that people with diabetes must avoid all sugar and starchy foods; they can be eaten as part of a balanced meal plan.
Source: American Diabetes Association (https://diabetes.org/health-wellness/health-care-professionals/myths-about-diabetes)
data.cure:
There is currently no cure for Type 1 or Type 2 diabetes. Treatment for both types involves lifelong management of blood sugar levels through medication (like insulin), diet, and exercise. While there's no cure, Type 2 diabetes can sometimes go into remission with intensive lifestyle management, particularly significant weight loss.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/basics/cures.html)

data.about:
Pregnancy is the physiological state during which a woman carries a developing embryo or fetus in her uterus. It typically lasts for about 40 weeks, or just over 9 months, from the last menstrual period to childbirth.
Source: Office on Women's Health (https://www.womenshealth.gov/pregnancy)
data.symptoms:
Early signs and symptoms include a missed menstrual period, tender or swollen breasts, nausea with or without vomiting (morning sickness), increased urination, and fatigue. These are followed by fetal movement and gradual enlargement of the abdomen.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-lifestyle/getting-pregnant/in-depth/symptoms-of-pregnancy/art-20043853)
data.prevention:
In the context of health, prevention is focused on avoiding complications. This is achieved through regular prenatal care, a healthy diet including folic acid, avoiding alcohol and smoking, and managing pre-existing medical conditions.
Source: March of Dimes (https://www.marchofdimes.org/find-support/topics/planning-baby/your-checkup-you-get-pregnant)
data.transmission:
Pregnancy is a natural reproductive process and is not transmissible. However, certain infections can be transmitted from the mother to the developing fetus during pregnancy or childbirth.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/pregnancy/infections.html)
data.vaccine:
There is no vaccine related to causing or preventing pregnancy itself. However, certain vaccines (like flu and Tdap) are recommended during pregnancy to protect both mother and baby from infectious diseases.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pregnancy/index.html)
data.risk_factors:
Risk factors for pregnancy complications include advanced maternal age (over 35), being pregnant with multiples (twins, etc.), high blood pressure, diabetes, obesity, and other pre-existing health conditions.
Source: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/high-risk-pregnancy)
data.misconceptions:
A common myth is that you need to 'eat for two,' which can lead to excessive weight gain; only a modest increase in calories is needed. Another is that you can't exercise during pregnancy; in most cases, moderate exercise is safe and recommended.
Source: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (https://www.acog.org/womens-health/faqs/exercise-during-pregnancy)
data.cure:
Pregnancy is a natural physiological process, not a disease, so the concept of a 'cure' does not apply. It is a temporary state that concludes with childbirth, miscarriage, or termination.
Source: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancy)

data.about:
Malnutrition refers to deficiencies, excesses, or imbalances in a person’s intake of energy and/or nutrients. It covers two broad groups: 'undernutrition' (stunting, wasting, underweight) and 'overnutrition' (overweight, obesity, and diet-related noncommunicable diseases).
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/malnutrition)
data.symptoms:
Symptoms of undernutrition include weight loss, fatigue, dizziness, and slow growth in children. Symptoms of overnutrition include being overweight or obese. Both forms can lead to a weakened immune system and increased susceptibility to infection.
Source: NHS UK (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/malnutrition/symptoms/)
data.prevention:
Prevention involves ensuring access to and consumption of a safe, nutritious, and diverse diet. It includes promoting breastfeeding, improving access to healthy foods, providing nutritional education, and fortifying staple foods with micronutrients.
Source: UNICEF (https://www.unicef.org/nutrition/what-is-malnutrition)
data.transmission:
Malnutrition is not a contagious condition and cannot be passed from person to person. However, diseases that cause malnutrition (like intestinal parasites) can be contagious.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/malnutrition)
data.vaccine:
There is no vaccine for malnutrition itself. It is a nutritional state, not an infectious disease. However, vaccines for infectious diseases can help prevent malnutrition, as illness can affect nutrient absorption and appetite.
Source: Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance (https://www.gavi.org/vaccineswork/five-ways-vaccines-fight-malnutrition)
data.risk_factors:
Major risk factors include poverty, lack of access to nutritious food, digestive disorders or other diseases that affect nutrient absorption, and lack of nutritional knowledge. The very young and very old are particularly vulnerable.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/malnutrition/symptoms-causes/syc-20354045)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that malnutrition only means being underweight. A person who is obese can also be malnourished if their diet lacks essential vitamins and minerals. Another myth is that it only occurs in low-income countries; it is a problem in all countries.
Source: Action Against Hunger (https://www.actionagainsthunger.org/the-hunger-project/7-myths-about-hunger/)
data.cure:
Malnutrition is treatable and can be cured. The treatment depends on the type and severity but generally involves a carefully planned diet to provide the missing nutrients. This may include dietary changes, eating fortified foods, or taking specific nutritional supplements. Treating any underlying medical condition that causes malnutrition is also essential.
Source: NHS UK (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/malnutrition/treatment/)

data.about:
A congenital disorder, also known as a birth defect, is a condition present at birth regardless of its cause. These disorders can be structural or functional and can result from genetic factors, environmental factors, or a combination of both.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/ncbddd/birthdefects/facts.html)
data.symptoms:
Symptoms vary widely depending on the specific disorder. They can range from physical abnormalities visible at birth (like a cleft lip or spina bifida) to metabolic problems (like PKU) or developmental issues (like Down syndrome) that become apparent later.
Source: March of Dimes (https://www.marchofdimes.org/find-support/topics/birth-defects-and-health-conditions)
data.prevention:
Not all congenital disorders are preventable. However, risks can be reduced through measures like taking folic acid before and during pregnancy to prevent neural tube defects, avoiding alcohol and smoking, getting vaccinated, and managing maternal health conditions.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/birth-defects)
data.transmission:
Congenital disorders are not contagious. They cannot be spread from person to person after birth. Some are inherited genetically from parents, while others are caused by factors affecting development in the womb.
Source: Stanford Medicine Children's Health (https://www.stanfordchildrens.org/en/topic/default?id=overview-of-birth-defects-90-P02342)
data.vaccine:
There are no vaccines to prevent congenital disorders themselves. However, vaccines like the rubella and varicella vaccines prevent infections in the mother that can cause severe birth defects in the fetus.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pregnancy/vacc-before.html)
data.risk_factors:
Risk factors include a family history or genetic predisposition, advanced maternal age, unmanaged maternal health conditions like diabetes, use of certain medications, smoking, alcohol use during pregnancy, and certain infections.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/congenital-heart-defects-in-children/symptoms-causes/syc-20350074)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that all birth defects are caused by something the mother did wrong during pregnancy; many have unknown causes or are purely genetic. Another myth is that all congenital disorders are visible at birth; some may not be diagnosed until later in life.
Source: MedlinePlus (https://medlineplus.gov/birthdefects.html)
data.cure:
A cure depends entirely on the specific disorder. Some structural birth defects, like a cleft lip or certain heart defects, can be surgically corrected and effectively cured. However, many congenital disorders, particularly those caused by genetic abnormalities like Down syndrome, have no cure. Treatment for these conditions focuses on managing symptoms and supporting development and function throughout the person's life.
Source: MedlinePlus (https://medlineplus.gov/birthdefects.html)

data.about:
Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) are a group of disorders of the heart and blood vessels. They include coronary heart disease (heart attacks), cerebrovascular disease (stroke), high blood pressure (hypertension), peripheral artery disease, and heart failure.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/health-topics/cardiovascular-diseases)
data.symptoms:
Symptoms depend on the specific disease. For a heart attack, they include chest pain, pain in the arm or shoulder, and shortness of breath. For a stroke, symptoms are sudden weakness of the face or limbs. Often, there are no symptoms before the first event.
Source: American Heart Association (https://www.heart.org/en/health-topics/consumer-healthcare/what-is-cardiovascular-disease)
data.prevention:
The most important behavioral risk factors for CVDs can be addressed through prevention, including stopping tobacco use, reducing salt in the diet, consuming more fruit and vegetables, regular physical activity, and avoiding harmful use of alcohol.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/cardiovascular-diseases-(cvds))
data.transmission:
Cardiovascular diseases are non-communicable and are not contagious. They cannot be passed from one person to another.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/chronicdisease/resources/publications/factsheets/heart-disease-stroke.htm)
data.vaccine:
There are no vaccines for cardiovascular disease. It is a group of non-infectious conditions related to genetics, lifestyle, and environment.
Source: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/cardiovascular-diseases)
data.risk_factors:
Major risk factors include high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, smoking, physical inactivity, an unhealthy diet, and obesity. Family history and age are also significant factors.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/heart-disease/symptoms-causes/syc-20353118)
data.misconceptions:
A major myth is that heart disease is a 'man's disease.' It is the leading cause of death for women as well. Another misconception is that you shouldn't exercise after a heart attack; on the contrary, cardiac rehabilitation and exercise are vital for recovery.
Source: American Heart Association (https://www.heart.org/en/health-topics/consumer-healthcare/common-myths-about-heart-disease)
data.cure:
There is no cure for most cardiovascular diseases, as they are chronic conditions. However, they can be managed effectively with a combination of lifestyle changes (healthy diet, exercise, smoking cessation), medications (to control blood pressure, cholesterol), and medical procedures or surgery when necessary. The goal of treatment is to control symptoms, slow progression, and reduce the risk of events like a heart attack or stroke.
Source: American Heart Association (https://www.heart.org/en/health-topics/consumer-healthcare/what-is-cardiovascular-disease)

data.about:
A mental disorder (or mental illness) is a health condition involving changes in emotion, thinking, or behavior. It is associated with distress and/or problems functioning in social, work, or family activities. Examples include depression, anxiety disorders, schizophrenia, and eating disorders.
Source: American Psychiatric Association (https://www.psychiatry.org/patients-families/what-is-mental-illness)
data.symptoms:
Symptoms vary greatly depending on the specific disorder. They can include changes in mood (e.g., prolonged sadness), personality changes, social withdrawal, extreme anxiety or paranoia, changes in sleep or eating patterns, and difficulty coping with daily problems.
Source: National Institute of Mental Health (https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/signs-symptoms-mental-disorders)
data.prevention:
Prevention focuses on reducing risk factors and promoting protective factors. This can include addressing stress, building social and emotional skills, seeking help for early signs, and fostering supportive relationships and communities.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/mental-disorders)
data.transmission:
Mental disorders are not contagious and cannot be passed from person to person like an infection. They arise from a complex interplay of genetic, biological, psychological, and environmental factors.
Source: MentalHealth.gov (https://www.mentalhealth.gov/basics/what-is-mental-health)
data.vaccine:
There is no vaccine for mental disorders. They are complex health conditions, not infectious diseases.
Source: National Institute of Mental Health (https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/topics/)
data.risk_factors:
Risk factors include a family history of mental illness, traumatic life experiences (like abuse or combat), chronic medical conditions, use of alcohol or drugs, and feelings of isolation or loneliness.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/mental-illness/symptoms-causes/syc-20374968)
data.misconceptions:
A pervasive myth is that mental illness is a sign of weakness or a character flaw; it is a medical condition, not a choice. Another misconception is that people with mental disorders cannot recover; with proper treatment, many people recover fully and lead productive lives.
Source: NAMI (National Alliance on Mental Illness) (https://www.nami.org/get-involved/stigmafree/mental-health-myths-and-facts)
data.cure:
While the term 'cure' is not often used, recovery from a mental disorder is possible for many individuals. Treatment, which may include psychotherapy, medication, and support services, can significantly reduce symptoms and allow a person to live a full, productive life. For some, mental illness may be a lifelong condition that requires ongoing management, similar to other chronic health conditions like diabetes or heart disease.
Source: National Institute of Mental Health (https://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/topics/)

data.about:
Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral infection found in tropical and subtropical climates worldwide. It is caused by one of four related viruses: DENV-1, DENV-2, DENV-3, and DENV-4. Infection with one serotype provides lifelong immunity to it but increases the risk of developing severe dengue if infected with a different serotype later.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/dengue-and-severe-dengue)
data.symptoms:
Dengue symptoms typically begin 4–10 days after infection and can include high fever (40°C/104°F), severe headache, pain behind the eyes, muscle and joint pains, nausea, vomiting, swollen glands, and rash. Severe dengue can result in serious complications.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/dengue-and-severe-dengue)
data.prevention:
The primary method of prevention is to avoid mosquito bites. This includes using insect repellent, wearing long-sleeved shirts and long pants, and ensuring windows and doors are secure. It is also vital to eliminate mosquito breeding sites by removing standing water from containers like flower pots, old tires, and buckets.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/dengue/prevention/index.html)
data.transmission:
Dengue is transmitted to humans through the bites of infected female Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes. These mosquitoes become infected when they bite a person with the dengue virus in their blood. The virus cannot be spread directly from person to person.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/dengue/transmission/index.html)
data.vaccine:
A vaccine called Dengvaxia is available for people ages 9–45 who live in areas with a high risk of dengue and have had a previous dengue infection. It is not recommended for individuals who have not been previously infected, as it may increase the risk of severe dengue in the future.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/dengue/vaccine/index.html)
data.risk_factors:
Individuals with weakened immune systems and those with a second or subsequent dengue infection are at greater risk of developing severe dengue. Infants, young children, and the elderly are also more vulnerable to complications.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/dengue-and-severe-dengue)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that dengue is only a 'tropical' disease, but it can occur in any area with the right mosquito vectors. It is also often mistaken for other illnesses like the flu. A second myth is that papaya leaf juice can cure dengue; while it may help with platelet counts, it is not a proven cure and should not replace medical treatment.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/emergencies/disease-outbreak-news/item/dengue-and-severe-dengue)
data.cure:
There is no specific cure for dengue fever. Treatment focuses on relieving symptoms and includes rest, hydration, and pain relievers like acetaminophen. Severe dengue requires hospital care to manage complications.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/dengue-fever/diagnosis-treatment/drc-20353084)

data.about:
Malaria is a life-threatening disease caused by parasites of the Plasmodium genus, transmitted to humans through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. There are five main species that infect humans: P. falciparum, P. vivax, P. malariae, P. ovale, and P. knowlesi. P. falciparum is the most prevalent and deadliest type.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/malaria)
data.symptoms:
Malaria symptoms include high fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, fatigue, and nausea. Symptoms typically appear 10 days to 4 weeks after being bitten by an infected mosquito but can also show up months later.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/malaria/about/symptoms.html)
data.prevention:
Prevention includes avoiding mosquito bites by using insecticide-treated mosquito nets, wearing protective clothing, and applying insect repellents. In some cases, a doctor may prescribe antimalarial drugs for travelers to at-risk areas.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/malaria)
data.transmission:
Malaria is caused by a parasite and is transmitted to humans through the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes. It is not transmitted from person to person through casual contact.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/malaria)
data.vaccine:
Yes, the RTS,S/AS01 malaria vaccine is recommended by the WHO to prevent malaria in children living in areas with high transmission rates.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/malaria)
data.risk_factors:
Living in or traveling to a tropical region with high malaria transmission rates, not using preventive measures like mosquito nets or repellent, and having a weakened immune system are risk factors. Young children and pregnant women are also particularly vulnerable.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/malaria)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that malaria is just a severe flu; however, it is a parasitic infection that can be life-threatening if not treated promptly. Another myth is that you can get malaria from being in a cold climate; the parasite needs a specific mosquito host, which is prevalent in tropical areas.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/malaria/about/faqs.html)
data.cure:
Malaria is a serious infection that requires treatment with medicine. Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) is the most effective treatment for P. falciparum malaria. Other drugs, like chloroquine, may be used for other types of malaria depending on the region and resistance.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/malaria)

data.about:
Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious infection caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily attacks the lungs (pulmonary TB), but can also affect other parts of the body, such as the kidney, spine, and brain (extrapulmonary TB). There are two main TB-related conditions: latent TB infection and active TB disease.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/tb/topic/basics/default.htm)
data.symptoms:
Tuberculosis primarily affects the lungs and common symptoms include a persistent cough (sometimes with blood), chest pain, weight loss, fever, and night sweats. Other parts of the body can also be affected, leading to a variety of symptoms.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/tuberculosis)
data.prevention:
The primary way to prevent TB is through the BCG vaccine, which is often given to infants and young children in countries with high TB rates. Early diagnosis and treatment of infected individuals are also key to preventing the spread of the disease.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/tuberculosis)
data.transmission:
TB is a contagious disease spread through the air when a person with active TB disease in their lungs coughs, sneezes, or spits. A person needs to inhale only a small number of these germs to become infected.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/tb/topic/basics/howtbspreads.htm)
data.vaccine:
Yes, the Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine is widely used in many countries to protect against severe forms of TB in children. It does not consistently prevent pulmonary TB in adults, which is the most common form.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/tuberculosis)
data.risk_factors:
People with weakened immune systems (such as those with HIV), malnourished individuals, those with diabetes, and people who use tobacco are at a higher risk. Close contact with a person who has active TB is also a major risk factor.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/tuberculosis)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that TB is a disease of the past and has been eliminated. However, it remains a serious global health issue. Another myth is that TB is always a death sentence, but with proper treatment, it is curable.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/questions-and-answers/item/tuberculosis)
data.cure:
Tuberculosis (TB) is a curable disease. The standard treatment involves a course of antibiotics that must be taken for several months. It is crucial to complete the entire course of medication to prevent the development of drug-resistant TB.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/tuberculosis)

data.about:
Diarrheal disease is defined as passing three or more loose or liquid stools per day. It is a leading cause of child mortality and is a symptom of infection in the intestinal tract caused by various bacterial, viral, and parasitic organisms. Clinically, it can be categorized into three types: acute watery diarrhea, acute bloody diarrhea (dysentery), and persistent diarrhea.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/diarrhoeal-disease)
data.symptoms:
Diarrheal diseases are characterized by loose, watery stools. Other symptoms can include stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and dehydration.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/diarrhoeal-disease)
data.prevention:
Key prevention measures include access to safe drinking water, improved sanitation and hygiene, and exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months of life. Hand washing with soap is also crucial.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/diarrhoeal-disease)
data.transmission:
Diarrhea-causing infections are primarily spread through contaminated food and water, often from feces. They can also be spread from person to person due to poor hygiene.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/diarrhoeal-disease)
data.vaccine:
Yes, there is a rotavirus vaccine which is part of routine childhood immunization schedules. Rotavirus is a major cause of severe diarrhea in young children.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/teams/immunization-vaccines-and-biologicals/diseases/rotavirus)
data.risk_factors:
Risk factors include a lack of access to clean water and sanitation, poor hygiene, and malnutrition. Children, particularly those under five years of age, are most vulnerable.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/diarrhoeal-disease)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that diarrhea is not a serious condition, but it is a leading cause of death in young children. Another myth is that one should stop eating during a diarrheal episode, but it's important to continue a nutritious diet to avoid malnutrition.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/diarrhoeal-disease)
data.cure:
Most cases of sudden diarrhea clear on their own. The primary treatment is rehydration with oral rehydration salts (ORS) to replace lost fluids and electrolytes, along with zinc supplements. Antibiotics may be used for specific bacterial or parasitic infections.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/diarrhoeal-disease)

data.about:
Leptospirosis is a bacterial disease that affects both humans and animals, caused by bacteria of the genus Leptospira. A severe form of the illness, known as Weil's disease, can develop and may result in life-threatening complications like kidney damage, liver failure, and meningitis.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/leptospirosis/index.html)
data.symptoms:
Symptoms can range from mild to severe, and they often mimic other diseases. They include high fever, headache, muscle aches, vomiting, and chills. In severe cases, it can lead to kidney damage, meningitis, and liver failure.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/leptospirosis/symptoms/index.html)
data.prevention:
Prevention involves avoiding contact with water or soil that may be contaminated with the urine of infected animals. This includes using protective clothing when working outdoors and staying away from floodwaters. Rodent control is also a key preventive measure.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/leptospirosis/prevention/index.html)
data.transmission:
Leptospirosis is caused by bacteria and is transmitted through contact with the urine of infected animals, often through contaminated water, soil, or food. It is not typically spread from person to person.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/leptospirosis/transmission/index.html)
data.vaccine:
While vaccines are available for animals, there is no widely available human vaccine for Leptospirosis. In some high-risk areas, a human vaccine is used, but the primary focus of prevention is on avoiding exposure.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/leptospirosis)
data.risk_factors:
People who work outdoors with animals, such as farmers and veterinarians, are at high risk. Exposure to floodwaters or contaminated bodies of water for recreational activities also increases the risk.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/leptospirosis/risk/index.html)
data.misconceptions:
A misconception is that leptospirosis is only found in developing countries, but it is a global issue. Another myth is that you can only get it from rats, but many different animals, including livestock and dogs, can carry the bacteria.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/leptospirosis)
data.cure:
Leptospirosis is treated with antibiotics, such as doxycycline or penicillin. Treatment should begin as early as possible after symptoms appear to prevent severe illness.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/leptospirosis/treatment/index.html)

data.about:
Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a serious viral brain infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV). It is a flavivirus, related to the viruses that cause dengue and West Nile fever, and is spread to humans through the bites of infected mosquitoes, primarily of the Culex species.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/japanese-encephalitis)
data.symptoms:
Most people infected with the virus show no symptoms. For those who do, symptoms can include fever, headache, vomiting, and confusion. In severe cases, it can lead to seizures, paralysis, and coma.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/japanese-encephalitis)
data.prevention:
Prevention focuses on avoiding mosquito bites and vaccination. Using mosquito nets, insect repellent, and wearing protective clothing are key. A vaccine is available for travelers and is part of routine childhood immunization in many high-risk areas.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/japaneseencephalitis/prevention/index.html)
data.transmission:
Japanese Encephalitis is transmitted to humans through the bites of infected Culex mosquitoes. The virus is maintained in a transmission cycle between mosquitoes and pigs and wading birds. It is not spread from person to person.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/japanese-encephalitis)
data.vaccine:
Yes, a safe and effective vaccine for Japanese Encephalitis is available. It is recommended for travelers to endemic areas, and some countries have mass immunization programs for children.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/japaneseencephalitis/vaccine/index.html)
data.risk_factors:
The main risk factor is living in or traveling to an area where Japanese Encephalitis is common. Children, especially in rural areas where pigs and wading birds are present, are at the highest risk.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/japanese-encephalitis)
data.misconceptions:
A misconception is that Japanese Encephalitis is only a problem in Japan, but it is found in many countries across Asia and the Western Pacific. Another myth is that you can get it from a person; it is transmitted by mosquitoes.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/japaneseencephalitis/qa/index.html)
data.cure:
There is no specific cure for Japanese Encephalitis. Treatment is supportive, focusing on managing symptoms such as with intravenous (IV) fluids, fever-reducing medication, and anticonvulsants for seizures.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/japanese-encephalitis)

data.about:
Jaundice is not a disease itself, but a visible sign of an underlying condition where there is too much bilirubin in the blood. It is categorized into three main types based on the cause: pre-hepatic (increased bilirubin production), hepatocellular (liver disease or injury), and post-hepatic (bile duct blockage).
Source: Cleveland Clinic (https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/15367-jaundice-in-adults)
data.symptoms:
Jaundice is a condition where the skin and whites of the eyes turn yellow due to high levels of bilirubin in the blood. Other symptoms can include pale stools, dark urine, and itching.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/infant-jaundice/symptoms-causes/syc-20373865)
data.prevention:
Jaundice is a symptom of an underlying condition, so prevention depends on the cause. Maintaining a healthy diet, limiting alcohol intake, and getting vaccinated for hepatitis A and B can help prevent some liver diseases that cause jaundice.
Source: Cleveland Clinic (https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/15367-jaundice-in-adults)
data.transmission:
Jaundice itself is not transmissible from person to person, but some of the underlying conditions that cause it, such as hepatitis, can be.
Source: Cleveland Clinic (https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/15367-jaundice-in-adults)
data.vaccine:
There is no vaccine for jaundice, but there are vaccines for some of the diseases that can cause it, such as hepatitis A and B.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/hepatitis-a)
data.risk_factors:
Risk factors for jaundice include underlying liver diseases such as hepatitis, cirrhosis, and gallstones. Certain medications and excessive alcohol consumption also increase the risk.
Source: Cleveland Clinic (https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/15367-jaundice-in-adults)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that jaundice is a disease in itself; it is actually a symptom of an underlying condition. Another myth is that it only affects newborns, but adults can also develop jaundice due to various health issues.
Source: NHS UK (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/jaundice-in-adults/)
data.cure:
There is no specific cure for jaundice itself as it is a symptom of an underlying condition. Treatment focuses on addressing the root cause, such as an infection or liver disease.
Source: Cleveland Clinic (https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/15367-jaundice-in-adults)

data.about:
Rickettsioses are a group of diseases caused by bacteria from the Rickettsia family. These infections are transmitted to humans through the bites of infected arthropods like ticks, mites, fleas, and lice. The diseases are generally divided into two main categories: the spotted fever group and the typhus group.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/ticks/rickettsial-diseases/index.html)
data.symptoms:
Symptoms often start with fever, headache, and a rash that may not appear in all cases. These can be mild or severe, and they vary depending on the specific type of rickettsial infection.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/otherspottedfever/symptoms/index.html)
data.prevention:
Prevention primarily involves avoiding arthropod (tick, flea, mite) bites. This includes using insect repellent, wearing protective clothing, and checking for and removing ticks after being outdoors.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/ticks/avoid/on_people.html)
data.transmission:
Rickettsial diseases are caused by bacteria and are transmitted through the bite of infected arthropods such as ticks, fleas, and mites.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/ticks/rickettsial-diseases/index.html)
data.vaccine:
There is currently no vaccine available for most rickettsial diseases. Prevention through avoidance of arthropod bites is the most effective strategy.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/rmsf/prevention/index.html)
data.risk_factors:
Risk factors include spending time in wooded, bushy, or grassy areas where ticks and other arthropods are common. People who work or live in close contact with animals are also at a higher risk.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/ticks/rickettsial-diseases/index.html)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that rickettsial diseases are not a significant threat, but they can be severe and even fatal if not treated promptly. Another myth is that they are only a problem in certain regions; they are found worldwide.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/ticks/rickettsial-diseases/index.html)
data.cure:
Rickettsial diseases are treated with antibiotics. Doxycycline is the first-line treatment and is highly effective when started within the first five days of symptoms.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/otherspottedfever/treatment/index.html)

data.about:
Chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted by infected mosquitoes, causing fever and severe joint pain. The name means 'to become contorted,' describing the stooped appearance of sufferers. The disease shares clinical signs with dengue and Zika, leading to potential misdiagnosis.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/chikungunya)
data.symptoms:
High fever, severe joint and muscle pain, headache, rash, nausea, fatigue.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/symptoms/index.html)
data.prevention:
Mosquito bite avoidance via repellents, protective clothing, vector control.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/prevention/index.html)
data.transmission:
Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, active during daylight hours, biting indoors and outdoors.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/transmission/index.html)
data.vaccine:
A vaccine called IXCHIQ is approved in the United States for people 18 years and older who are at increased risk of exposure to the virus.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/vaccine/index.html)
data.risk_factors:
Proximity to mosquito breeding sites and traveling to areas with ongoing outbreaks.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/chikungunya)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that Chikungunya is the same as dengue; while symptoms are similar, they are caused by different viruses. Another is that joint pain is always short-lived, but it can persist for months or years in some people.
Source: WHO (https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/chikungunya)
data.cure:
There is no specific cure for Chikungunya. Treatment is supportive, focusing on managing symptoms with rest, fluids, and pain relievers like acetaminophen.
Source: CDC (https://www.cdc.gov/chikungunya/treatment/index.html)

data.about:
Acne is a common skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become plugged with oil and dead skin cells, leading to pimples, blackheads, or whiteheads. It can be classified into non-inflammatory types (blackheads, whiteheads) and inflammatory types (papules, pustules, nodules, cysts).
Source: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases (https://www.niams.nih.gov/health-topics/acne)
data.symptoms:
Pimples, nodules, cysts. Acne can also lead to disfiguring scars and dark spots on the skin.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/acne/symptoms-causes/syc-20368047)
data.prevention:
Prevention includes gentle skincare, avoiding harsh scrubbing, using non-comedogenic products, and consulting a dermatologist. Regular cleaning of the skin and not picking at pimples are also key preventive measures.
Source: American Academy of Dermatology Association (https://www.aad.org/public/diseases/acne/skin-care/tips)
data.transmission:
Acne is an inflammatory condition of the skin pores and is not contagious. It cannot be spread from person to person.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/acne/symptoms-causes/syc-20368047)
data.vaccine:
No vaccine is available. Acne is not a viral or bacterial infection that spreads between people, so a vaccine is not a feasible preventive measure.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/acne/symptoms-causes/syc-20368047)
data.risk_factors:
Hormonal changes (during puberty, menstrual cycles), stress, certain medications, and a family history of acne are all risk factors.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/acne/symptoms-causes/syc-20368047)
data.misconceptions:
A common misconception is that acne is caused by poor hygiene or a poor diet. While proper skincare can help, the primary causes are hormonal and genetic. Another myth is that you can't get acne after puberty, but it can affect adults as well.
Source: American Academy of Dermatology Association (https://www.aad.org/public/diseases/acne/causes/myths)
data.cure:
There is no single 'cure' for acne, but it is a highly treatable condition. Treatment options range from topical creams and gels containing ingredients like retinoids and benzoyl peroxide to oral medications like antibiotics for more severe cases.
Source: Mayo Clinic (https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/acne/diagnosis-treatment/drc-20368048)
